title:
The Perceived Learning Behaviors and Assessment Techniques of First-Year
  Students in Computer Science: An Empirical Study
authors: Manuela Andreea Petrescu and Tudor Dan Mihoc
abstract:
The objective of our study is to ascertain the present learning behaviors,
driving forces, and assessment techniques as perceived by first-year students,
and to examine them through the lens of the most recent developments (pandemic,
shift to remote instruction, return to in-person instruction). Educators and
educational institutions can create a more accommodating learning environment
that takes into account the varied needs and preferences of students by
recognizing and implementing these findings, which will ultimately improve the
quality of education as a whole. Students believe that in-person instruction is
the most effective way to learn, with exercise-based learning, group
instruction, and pair programming. Our research indicates that, for evaluation
methods, there is a preference for practical and written examinations. Our
findings also underscore the importance of incorporating real-world scenarios,
encouraging interactive learning approaches, and creating engaging educational
environments.
